channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Transfers 6 Guantánamo Detainees to Uruguay
item.description: The transfer announced by the Defense Department was the largest single group of inmates to leave the prison in Cuba since 2009.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: As Ebola Rages, Poor Planning Thwarts Efforts
item.description: Aid officials in Sierra Leone say weak coordination among aid groups, government mismanagement and glaring inefficiencies are costing countless lives.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A lab technician from the Sierra Leone Health Ministry with a cooler of blood samples from suspected Ebola patients. Delays in testing are causing serious bottlenecks at treatment centers.

item.title: London Journal: Forget the Hounds. As Foxes Creep In, Britons Call the Sniper.
item.description: “They may appear cuddly and romantic, but foxes are also a pest and a menace,” Mayor Boris Johnson said. Some in London, however, are working to save the animals from harm.
item.category: Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phil, a fox sniper, disposed of a fox he shot in London in October. There are more foxes in London than double-decker buses.

item.title: Woman Accuses Uber Driver in India of Rape
item.description: The authorities in New Delhi are searching for a suspect who is said to have assaulted a woman while taking her home late Friday.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Remains of Student in Mexico Identified
item.description: A lab’s finding lends credence to a theory that the police abducted 43 students and turned them over to a drug gang, which killed them.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Relatives of some of the 43 missing students gathered to protest in Mexico City on Saturday. The remains of one have been identified, an official said.

item.title: Eyeing Return, Ex-President in France Has Hurdles
item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy’s first week as leader of the Union for a Popular Movement Party seemed to prove only that he had determined rivals within the party and was not assured of becoming its presidential candidate.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former French president, is now the leader of the conservative Union for a Popular Movement Party, but he is facing rivals within the party and has made missteps.

item.title: Facing Rights Accusations, Israel Opens Gaza Inquiries
item.description: The Israeli military ordered eight additional criminal investigations into the conduct of its forces during the war this summer in the Gaza Strip.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: 2 Hostages Killed in Yemen as U.S. Rescue Effort Fails
item.description: Luke Somers, a journalist, and Pierre Korkie, a teacher, were being held by Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen when they died during a raid by United States commandos Saturday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Luke Somers, an American photojournalist, in Sana, the Yemeni capital, in 2013. He had been captured by Al Qaeda.

item.title: Back to a Burmese Prison by Choice
item.description: U Htein Lin was detained for more than six years in Myanmar as a political prisoner, but has recently returned to teach meditation to the prisoners and the guards.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Minzayar for The New York Times
item.media:description: U Htein Lin, at his home in Yangon, Myanmar, says he made some of his best work in prison.

item.title: Vegetable Spawns Larceny and Luxury in Peru
item.description: As maca booms, some Peruvians fear that they are losing control of a valuable crop with a history that goes back long before the time of the Inca empire.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Pakistani Military Kills a Qaeda Leader
item.description: The country’s military said that Adnan G. el-Shukrijumah, who was in charge of all external operations for Al Qaeda, was killed during an intelligence operation.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN
item.media:credit: FBI, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Quick History: A Week of Facts vs. Interpretation
item.description: There are no facts, only interpretations, Nietzsche said, and there was good evidence of that this past week, from Staten Island to Russia.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: A demonstrator being arrested in late November at a protest in New York against a decision not to indict a white police officer who killed an unarmed black man in Ferguson, Mo.

item.title: News Analysis: The Golden Age
item.description: Hoarding gold is the economy’s comfort food.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN FEUER

item.title: Athens Erupts 6 Years After Police Killing
item.description: Demonstrations in Athens and other Greek cities erupted in memory of Alexandros Grigoropoulos, who was 15 when he was shot dead by the police.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Protesters in Athens threw firebombs at a rally on the sixth anniversary of the fatal shooting of a teenager by the police.

item.title: After a Feud, Lawmakers in Somalia Oust Premier
item.description: The vote of no confidence ended the prime minister’s tenure after about a year, and it came after a dispute with the president over a cabinet reshuffle.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Swiss Hostage Escapes Rebels During Philippine Army Raid
item.description: The Swiss national, Lorenzo Vinciguerra, had been held for more than two years by Abu Sayyaf militants in the southern Philippines.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Typhoon Lashes Philippines, Amid Fears of a Repeat of Last Year’s Devastation
item.description: A major concern is that the storm is expected to take up to three days to move across the central Philippines, dumping heavy rains and raising the possibility of deadly landslides.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Evacuations continued on Samar Island in the Philippines on Saturday.

item.title: British Judge Lifts Restriction on Sending Books to Prisoners
item.description: A policy had prohibited inmates from receiving books unless they had earned the right through good behavior to buy them through the Prison Service.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: 1,000 Extra U.S. Soldiers Will Remain in Afghanistan
item.description: The extra deployments appear to be intended to meet personnel requirements necessary to maintain bases across the country, including Kandahar Airfield.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel visiting Kabul on Saturday.

item.title: Hong Kong Protester Ends Hunger Strike
item.description: The 18-year-old who has become the face of the city’s pro-democracy protests said Saturday that his doctor had advised him to end the strike.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Joshua Wong on Saturday in Hong Kong after he ended a hunger strike.
